column1: Oeiras (Portuguese pronunciation: [oˈɐjɾɐʃ] (listen)) is a municipality in the western part of Lisbon metropolitan area
column2: a subregion of Greater Lisbon
column3: in continental Portugal. It is part of the urban agglomeration of Lisbon
column4: 16 km from the capital. The population in 2011 was 172
column5: 120 living in an area of 45.88 km2
column6: making the municipality the fifth-most densely populated in Portugal.

column1: Oeiras is an important economic hub
column2: being one of the most highly developed municipalities of Portugal and Europe. It has the highest GDP per capita in the country
column3: being also the second highest municipality (immediately after Lisbon) in terms of purchasing power as well as the second one collecting taxes in the country. These economic indicators also reflect the education level of the inhabitants
column4: as Oeiras is the municipality with the highest concentration of population with higher education in the country. It also has the lowest unemployment rate in the Lisbon area.

column2: access to water
column3: quality of its soils and geographically advantageous location at the mouth of the Tagus River attracted early settlement to this region. The rugged hilltops of the interior conditioned cultivation and allowed the settlement of several small agricultural castros within the region's limits
column4: such as Castro of Leceia (which was classified in 1963 as a property of public interest). This archaeological site is a witness to the early settlements and defensive structures that developed during the Chalcolithic period
column5: although Paleolithic camps such as Gruta da Ponte da Laje are indicative of earlier settlements.

column1: Remnants of the Roman occupation of the Iberian peninsula are evident in many places throughout the municipality
column2: including mosaics
column3: specifically along the Rua das Alcássimas
column4: and a Roman bridge. The later Arab conquest left behind several toponymic markers
column5: including Arab/Moorish place names such as Alcássimas

column1: The settlement of Oeiras dates back to 1208
column2: when the area was colonized by Christian tribes from the northern Portugal
column3: moving south into warmer agricultural lands.

column1: At the beginning of the Age of Discoveries
column2: Oeiras became the industrial and commercial warehouse of Lisbon. The development of the Gunpowder Factory (Portuguese: Fábrica da Pólvora) in Barcarena was therefore important in the expansion of the Portuguese dominions of the Orient
column3: in addition to the aggregate extraction and calcium oxide furnaces in Paço de Arcos. These industries were supported and guarded by the construction of several fortifications along a maritime defensive line that ringed the southern coast to Lisbon and that controlled navigation in the Tagus estuary from the 16th to 18th centuries. This perimeter included the Fort of São Lourenço da Cabeça Seca (also known as the Lighthouse or Tower of Bugio)
column4: rising from a tiny islet in the middle of the Tagus River
column5: as well as the Fort of São Julião da Barra
column6: both examples of Renaissance military architecture.

column1: The municipality was founded in 1759 by the Marquis of Pombal on an area granted as a reward by King Joseph I to his minister for his efforts in rebuilding Lisbon's historical downtown (Portuguese: Baixa) after the 1755 Lisbon earthquake. A royal charter
column2: dated 7 June 1759
column3: gave jurisdiction over the lands within Oeiras to the King's loyal minister
column4: who became the first Count of Oeiras. A month later
column5: the small village was elevated to the status of town
column6: and then gained municipal status on 13 June 1759. Although Oeiras had a history of earlier settlement
column7: it was during the reign of Joseph I that economic and social development
column8: conditioned by the influence of the King's Minister
column9: who promoted innovation and supported local economic activities

column2: the first agricultural and industrial fair was established in Oeiras
column3: representing a unique national event that also contributed to the creation of fishing shelters and a new customhouse and factory
column4: among other projects. One of the principal developments was the construction of the estate of the Marquess of Pombal
column5: which today exists in its original form

column2: the municipality was abolished
column3: but it was reestablished four years later on 13 January 1898. It was reconstituted without Carcavelos
column5: while gaining the civil parish of Benfica. In the late 17th and early 18th centuries
column6: several estates and palaces began to be constructed in order to explore agricultural production
column8: which supported the growing markets of Lisbon. However

column1: In the late 19th and early 20th centuries
column2: the growth of leisure activities along the coast transformed Oeiras
column3: which became a privileged location for the Portuguese elite. By the beginning of the 20th century
column4: many of the beaches in Oeiras were already occupied by the higher social classes
column5: who travelled to the municipality for medical reasons (believing the air and beach-waters were therapeutic). The construction of National Roadway 6 (EN6) would later link Lisboa to Cascais
column6: permitting new travellers to experience the area
column7: resulting in an influx of new residents that expanded the urban centres
column8: giving rise to beach "chalets" and summer cottages. Simultaneously
column9: the concentration of economic activities in Lisbon and surrounding urban municipalities meant that Oeiras had direct access to the capital.

column2: the municipality began to function as a suburb and bedroom community
column3: attracting more residential growth along the coast. This culminated in the 1970s with the appearance of illegal urban settlements
column5: the municipality was dependent on the much larger urban centre for development.

column2: however
column3: Oeiras began to constitute its own economic pole in the Lisbon metropolitan area
column4: concentrating its development on tertiary activities linked to science
column6: information technology and communications. At the end of the 20th century
column7: the municipality became known for its high standard of living
column8: leaving behind its image as a suburb of Lisbon and assuming an important position as a centre associated with new technologies (with the establishment of various technology parks
column9: such as Taguspark and LagoasPark) and service industries. The elevated standard of living and work allowed the region to obtain several awards
column10: including the Melhor Concelho para Trabalhar ('Best Municipality to Work')
column12: European Enterprise Award and the ECOXXI Award.

The final matches of the Portuguese Men's and Women's Football Cups traditionally take place in the Estádio Nacional in the Jamor complex.
The Portugal Open (previously known as Estoril Open) was an ATP and WTA tennis tournament held in the sports complex of Jamor

column1: The municipality is served by the Cascais Line
column2: a suburban railway line the runs along the Estoril Coast west from Lisbon.  There are six railway stations on the Cascais Line in the municipality

column1: Oeiras formerly contained the SATUOeiras people mover that connected Oeiras Parque Shopping Center with Paço de Arcos.  The line operated between 2004 and 2015.
